title: Mike Pawlawski
text:
Mike Pawlawski (born July 18, 1969) is a former professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player, a <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>, <a href="Arena%20Football%20League">Arena Football League</a>, and <a href="XFL%20%282001%29">XFL</a>.
Born in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, Pawlawski played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Berkeley">University of California</a> and led the <a href="California%20Golden%20Bears%20football">Golden Bears</a> to a 10–2 record and a #8 national ranking in <a href="1991%20California%20Golden%20Bears%20football%20team">1991</a>. He was selected by the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a> in the eighth round of the <a href="1992%20NFL%20Draft">1992 NFL Draft</a>, playing one season for the team.
After spending 1993 and 1994 out of football, Pawlawski signed with the Arena Football League, playing his inaugural season with the <a href="Miami%20Hooters">Miami Hooters</a>, then the next five with the <a href="Albany%20Firebirds">Albany Firebirds</a> where he established several league records and won Arena Bowl XIII Pawlawski finished his career with the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Demons">San Francisco Demons</a> of the XFL, where he led his team to an appearance in the <a href="Million%20Dollar%20Game">league championship</a>. He was one of only three quarterbacks (<a href="Tommy%20Maddox">Tommy Maddox</a> and <a href="Jim%20Druckenmiller">Jim Druckenmiller</a> being the other two) to last the whole XFL season without being injured or losing their job. It was later revealed, however, that Pawlawski had played the season with a fractured vertebra in his neck. It ended his football career.
He is currently the host of Gridiron Outdoors on <a href="Outdoor%20Channel">Outdoor Channel</a> and a <a href="color%20commentator">color commentator</a> for Cal football on <a href="Comcast%20SportsNet">Comcast SportsNet</a> and <a href="Fox%20Sports%20Net">Fox Sports Net</a>.
